list.title: Common: Utility function, Demand Functions, Calculating optimal bundle

list.text: Partial demand functions (dep. only on own price)
The optimal consumption bundle at current prices and incomes
Round the values for display purposes below

Below are equations for compensated demand. Basically, when solving for the conventional (uncompensated) demand, we solve the system of 2 equations:

 | p_1x+p_2y=I
<
 | MRS(x,y)=p_1/p_2

Which results in solutions X(p_1,p_2,I) and Y(p_1,p_2,I), which in turn can be used both to get the optimal solution and to trace the demand on Q/P axis.

However, for the compensated demand, we want to solve another system:

 | MRS(x,y)=p_1/p_2'
<
 | u(x,y) = u(d_x,d_y)=u*

The new pair X_c(p_1,p_2,p_2',I) and Y_c(p_1,p_2,p_2',I) can now be used for several purposes, such as:
calculating the compensating variation (additional income needed to sustain the utility)
showing the arrows
most importantly - defining the compensated demand as D_c(p)= X_c(p,p_2,p_2',I)
Define functions for rounding and solving quadratic equations
Opacity parameter to hide consumption curves when demonstrating comp demand:

note: the Vector function creates a list of points (ordered pairs), which define the vertices of an arrow. To see an arrow and not points the Desmos settings need to be adjusted to have "points" off and "lines" on
